channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Keeping Online Testing Honest? Or an Orwellian Overreach?
item.description: The rise of proctoring software to deter cheating alarms privacy advocates. Some students and professors find it invasive, too.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel Farzannekou, right, rebelled against an online proctoring system by grabbing a notepad from his girlfriend, Emily Louie, left, and holding a handwritten profanity up to the webcam.

item.title: A Lifetime of Running With Ahmaud Arbery Ends With a Text: ‘We Lost Maud’
item.description: Ahmaud Arbery and Akeem Baker were best friends who treated each other as brothers. With one now gone, the other struggles to move on.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset

item.title: Questions of Bias in Covid-19 Treatment Add to the Mourning for Black Families
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have advised health professionals to be on the lookout for medical bias.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ami Relf, right, holds a photo of her brother Reginald Relf alongside her mother, Cleona Relf, outside her mother’s home in Bellwood, Ill. Mr. Relf died there while quarantining in the basement after experiencing symptoms of Covid-19.

item.title: Mother’s Day and Coronavirus: Advice From 5 Mothers
item.description: Try to laugh, trust your own judgment and concentrate on your baby.
item.dc:creator: Shreeya Sinha
item.media:description: Emily Fazio delivered Josie, her second child.

item.title: Indiana Attorney General Suspended by State Supreme Court in Groping Case
item.description: Curtis T. Hill Jr., a Republican, had his law license suspended for 30 days after the court found that he inappropriately touched four women at a party in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Robert Franklin/South Bend Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Curtis Hill, Indiana’s attorney general, in February. He has resisted bipartisan calls to resign.

item.title: App Shows Promise in Tracking New Coronavirus Cases, Study Finds
item.description: The app, which allows people to record their symptoms, was remarkably effective in predicting infections. The most reliable indicators, researchers found, were loss of smell and taste.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: The Covid Symptom Study, developed by Zoe Global, a health science company, in collaboration with Massachusetts General Hospital and King’s College in London, had 2.5 million users who reported their symptoms in four weeks.

item.title: Biden and Trump Fundraising: 2020 Campaigns Raised Over $60 Million in April
item.description: President Trump and the Republicans, who brought in slightly more, maintain a vast cash advantage. But Mr. Biden’s substantial haul is likely to buoy Democrats who are worried about his ability to compete financially.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coronavirus forced former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to shift to virtual campaigning and fund-raising in March.

item.title: Abba Eban Was the Last to Hold These Two Israeli Posts at Once. Next: Gilad Erdan.
item.description: A younger rival to Netanyahu is to become Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations and, in November, to Washington as well.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Gilead Erdan in 2017.

item.title: Why Are Some Planes So Packed With Passengers in a Pandemic?
item.description: Most flights are empty but some are still operating near capacity, frustrating travelers who say that airlines are not doing enough to keep them safe.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: An American Airlines flight after landing in Los Angeles in late April.

item.title: G.O.P. Split Over State Aid That Could Mostly Go to Democratic Strongholds
item.description: With governors and mayors pressing for more federal help to deal with the effects of the pandemic, a divide among Republicans is being driven by the political bent of the states that stand to benefit.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, leaving a luncheon with Senate Republicans in the Capitol last week. He is pushing for a substantial infusion of aid to states and localities with few restrictions.

item.title: Tribal Nations Face Most Severe Crisis in Decades as the Coronavirus Closes Casinos
item.description: Nearly 500 tribal casinos remain shut down during the pandemic, causing job losses to spike. The economic damage is spreading quickly, wreaking havoc on fragile tribal finances.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jack Healy
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The Emerald Queen Casino & Hotel in Tacoma, Wash. The closure of hundreds of tribal casinos in response to the coronavirus outbreak is eviscerating the revenues many Native American nations use to provide basic services.

item.title: The G.O.P.’s Pandemic Playbook
item.description: Republicans can flip a House seat in California, but they’re raising doubts about the voting anyway.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Federal Watchdog to Examine Official’s Role in Tribal Fund Distribution
item.description: The inspector general is also investigating allegations that the Interior Department inappropriately leaked sensitive tribal data.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Mark Walker
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The village of Kivalina, Alaska. Alaska Native corporations are for-profit businesses that support tribal villages.

item.title: Trump's Tax Returns Supreme Court Case: What You Need to Know
item.description: The court will hear highly anticipated arguments over whether the president’s accountants and bankers must disclose information about his financial affairs.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will hear cases concerning whether President Trump can block subpoenas to his accountants and bankers from Congress and New York prosecutors.

item.title: Ex-Justice Dept. Officials Lash Out at Barr Over Flynn and Stone Cases
item.description: The attorney general’s interventions damaged the Justice Department, argued the former officials, who were directly involved in the cases of the two Trump allies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr dismissed the charges against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, last week.

item.title: Coronavirus in Washington, D.C.: Capital Moves to Reopen, While City Hesitates
item.description: As the coronavirus hits the White House, Congress and D.C.’s poorest areas, many across the region are asking the Trump administration to proceed with caution.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:description: The Rev. Dr. Jo Ann Browning at a food drive organized by the Ebenezer A.M.E. Church in Fort Washington, Md. Washington and close-knit counties in Virginia and Maryland are more interwoven than perhaps any metro area in the country.

item.title: Fauci, Other Witnesses and Chairman Are Quarantined, but Hearing Must Go On
item.description: Tuesday’s hearing before the Senate Health Committee will be a chance for Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and other top health experts to speak to lawmakers, albeit by video, without President Trump nearby.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci will testify before Congress, remotely, on Tuesday.

item.title: Supreme Court Hears Cases on Whether Employment Bias Laws Cover Teachers at Religious Schools
item.description: The cases are the latest in a series the court has had before it considering the relationship between church and state.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The Supreme Court held the hearing remotely on Monday because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Aide Ousted From White House Reappears Again in Administration Job
item.description: Ezra Cohen-Watnick’s latest position in the Trump administration is as deputy assistant secretary of defense for counternarcotics and global threats.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ezra Cohen-Watnick’s job at the Pentagon will be his third stint in the administration.

item.title: Nashville N.A.A.C.P. Leader Finds Bull’s-Eye in His Yard
item.description: A suspect has been charged in the case, and the police have set up a mediation between the Rev. Keith Caldwell and a police officer who he said was dismissive of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:description: The Rev. Keith Caldwell found a plastic target with protruding bristles outside his home in Nashville on Saturday night.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Case: Georgia Attorney General Appoints Fourth Prosecutor
item.description: Joyette M. Holmes, an Atlanta-area district attorney, will take over a case that has stirred protests, as the Justice Department said it was weighing federal hate crimes charges.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Demonstrators watched a parade of motorcyclists riding in honor of Ahmaud Arbery in Brunswick, Ga.

item.title: After Months Apart, Mother’s Day VisitsThrough a Doorway
item.description: At a Los Angeles nursing home, families got their first chance to see Mom since the lockdown began — as long as they stayed outside, and she stayed in.
item.dc:creator: Isadora Kosofsky
item.media:description: The Botiz family reacted to seeing Beatrice Botiz, 82, through the doorway at Alexandria Care Center in Los Angeles on Sunday.

item.title: As States Rush to Reopen, Scientists Fear a Coronavirus Comeback
item.description: Officials are under pressure to restart the economy, but many states are moving too quickly, researchers say. The costs may be measured in lost lives.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A field hospital in Central Park last month. Though hospitalizations and deaths due to the coronavirus are declining, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has refused to set a date for easing restrictions in all parts of the state.

item.title: Supreme Court Weighs Whether Much of Oklahoma Is an Indian Reservation
item.description: The answer to the question could have vast implications for criminal prosecutions and for commerce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The justices made clear that they remained concerned about a decision that would require federal authorities to investigate and prosecute many crimes in eastern Oklahoma.

item.title: After 274 Years, Princeton Will Have Its First Black Valedictorian
item.description: Given Princeton’s troubled history with slavery, the valedictorian said he hoped the achievement “serves as inspiration to black students coming up behind me.”
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon
item.media:description: Nicholas Johnson, 22, is valedictorian of Princeton’s Class of 2020.

item.title: Study Offers Details of U.S. Children Severely Sickened by Coronavirus
item.description: Most of the 48 I.C.U. patients studied had pre-existing medical conditions, including two who died. Eighteen of the children were put on ventilators.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: Texas Children’s Hospital in Houston, which treated pediatric Covid-19 cases in late March and early April.

item.title: Three Weeks in April: An E.M.T. Crew Faces Exhaustion, Isolation and Death
item.description: A photojournalist switched careers and became an E.M.T. just months before the coronavirus pandemic hit. Recently, he brought his camera along to document what he and his crew are seeing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Renneisen
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency medical technicians, or E.M.T.s, carried a man in cardiac arrest out of his home in Yonkers, N.Y., earlier this month. He had shown symptoms of Covid-19 before medical staff arrived; he later died at the hospital.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: Calaveras Jumping Frog Jubilee is Canceled
item.description: Monday: In Angels Camp, a tradition is disrupted. Also: An election update.
item.dc:creator: Will McCarthy
item.media:description: The annual Calaveras Jumping Frog Jubilee in Angels Camp, Calif., has been held since 1928.

item.title: Natural Gas Exports Slow as Pandemic Reduces Global Demand
item.description: Businesses in the United States, Israel and other countries were planning to invest billions in export terminals. Now, those projects are being canceled or delayed.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas pipeline terminal in Ashkelon, Israel, refitted to export gas to Egypt.

item.title: On Politics: Coronavirus at the White House
item.description: Infection fears hit the West Wing, and more grim job numbers emerge: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Coronavirus, Iran, Jerry Stiller: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A memorial for Ahmaud Arbery near where he was shot in Brunswick, Ga. during a protest on Friday.

item.title: Coronavirus Live News and Updates
item.description: Officials are under pressure to restart the economy, but scientists warn that many states are moving too quickly. President Trump told a Chinese-American correspondent that she “should ask China” for an answer to her question about testing.

item.title: For Those Who Must Enforce Coronavirus Lockdowns in California, the Decisions Are Wrenching
item.description: Angela Alvarado, a veteran prosecutor in the Santa Clara district attorney’s office in California, has to weigh safety, freedom and the law as she fields complaints about stay-at-home violations.
item.dc:creator: Katey Rusch and Casey Smith

item.title: Why Kamala Harris Is Not Clamoring to Be Joe Biden's V.P. Candidate
item.description: The California senator is considered a potential running mate for Joe Biden. But unlike other possible contenders, she has avoided making a pitch for the ticket.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris has often been mentioned as a leading contender to be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate.

item.title: Colorado Hair Salons Are Reopening, With New Rules
item.description: At one salon, beauticians are now wearing face masks and gloves, and no walk-ins are allowed.
item.dc:creator: Markian Hawryluk

item.title: Joe Biden’s Time in Sarah Palin’s Shadow
item.description: What two strange months in 2008 taught the former vice president about the politics of grievance, and how that might help him pick a running mate of his own to take on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: The frenetic final months of the 2008 race, when Joe Biden and Sarah Palin faced off as vice-presidential contenders, stand as perhaps the most consequential stretch of Mr. Biden’s campaign career.

item.title: Fort Worth Shooting: In Crowd of Hundreds, 5 Wounded in Village Creek Park
item.description: It was not clear what such a large crowd was doing at the park in Fort Worth during the pandemic, the police said. Witnesses told officials at least 30 gunshots were heard.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:description: It was unclear what hundreds of people were doing in Village Creek Park at the time, the police said, especially during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Tesla plans to reopen its car factory in Fremont, Calif., in defiance of a local order.

item.title: Coronavirus World Tracker: Germany, Britain, Wuhan
item.description: As France, Russia and others eased restrictions, Germany watches warily as the rate the virus is spreading has risen there. And in Mexico City, while other sounds are muffled, street musicians play on.
